channel.title: Man forced to install Windows
channel.description:
[url=http://news.zdnet.com/2100-9588_22-6204348.html]http://news.zdnet.com/2100-9588_22-6204348.html[/url]
A Linux user who was jailed for uploading a film onto a peer-to-peer service has been told he will have to switch to Windows if he wants to use a computer again. Scott McCausland, who used to be an administrator of the EliteTorrents BitTorrent server before it was shut down by the FBI, pleaded guilty in 2006 to two copyright-related charges over the uploading of Star Wars: Episode III to the Internet. As a result, he was sentenced to five months in jail and five months' home confinement. McCausland--who also goes by the name "sk0t"--has since been released from jail, but on Tuesday he reported on his blog that the terms of his sentence meant he would have to install Windows if he wanted to use a computer during his probation. "I had a meeting with my probation officer today, and he told me that he has to install monitoring software onto my PC," wrote McCausland. "No big deal to me...that is part of my sentence." "However, their software doesn't support GNU/Linux (which is what I use)," continued McCausland. "So, he told me that if I want to use a computer, I would have to use an OS that the software can be installed on. Which basically means: Microsoft and monitoring software or no computer. I use Ubuntu 7.04 now, and they are trying to force me to switch. First they give me two felonies, then they throw me in prison, and now this." According to the Web site TorrentFreak, McCausland and his attorney will fight the situation. "It isn't the fact that I have to be monitored that bothers me, it is the fact that I have (to) restructure my life (different OS, different software on that OS) and that they would require (force) me to purchase software while I am currently unemployed and relatively unemployable with the two felonies that they gave me," McCausland said. "It is just a ridiculous situation."

item.title: Man forced to install Windows
item.dc:creator: @Monkey_wacko Monkey wacko
item.description:
@Monkey_wacko wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:3, topic:144906”]That is truly the worst sentence you could hand a man

I feel really sorry for that guy…[/quote]

[/quote]

It’s quite hard to get a job when you’ve just come out of jail.[/quote]tru dat. if you wre a business owner would u hire a felon?

item.title: Man forced to install Windows
item.dc:creator: @elementalelf elementalelf
item.description:
@elementalelf wrote:

[quote=“xxlegitxx, post:17, topic:144906”][quote author=elementalelf link=topic=198510.msg1769321#msg1769321 date=1190323207]
exception: i was aware of that, however its the easiest way to explain it to open source noobs. however i find most apps i try work on WINE, SCAR did
Yz85Racer: i realise that, however ive noticed most things do.

i wonder if he could get around it by using vmware on a linux box running windows
[/quote]

I am actually not an open source noob, I, for one, know that WINE is temperamental and probably will not support some random monitoring software that most Linux users would not use. I also know that WINE is an api layer and thus is not an emulator.

And do you think software within a virtual machine will be able to effectively monitor events that occur outside the vm?[/quote]
you may not be an open source noob, but im willing to bet the other 90% of thread participants are…

and of course i dont think the VMware monitoring software would be able to monitor activity outside of VM, thats my point, its an effective way of browsing without them knowing.

Read full topic

a) A linux skin on XP. Which means it’s just Windows.
b) A windows skin on linux. He still can’t run the monitoring software.
